name: Godfried, Jonkheer Roëll
special_notes: Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Jonkheer)

name: Aleksandr Blinov
description: The 1980 equestrian games were not a top competition, like the other Olympic Games, because almost all the top riders missed the competition due to the boycott. In the eventing competition, the Soviets were favored in both the individual and team competition, as in the other equestrian events at the 1980 Olympics, but did not meet expectations. The Soviets were upset by Italian Federico Roman Euro, so Aleksandr Blinov had to settle for an individual silver, while taking gold in the team event. Besides his two Olympic medals, Blinov was Soviet champion in 1972, 1976 and 1986. After his sporting career, Blinov worked as an eventing coach with Spartak Moskva.

name: Yekaterina Kalinchuk
description: Yekaterina Kalinchuk took up gymnastics in 1936 and was on the Soviet national team from 1948-52. Kalinchuk’s only international tournament was the 1952 Olympics, where she won golds in horse vault and team all-around and silver in team portable apparatus. Domestically Kalinchuk won the Soviet title on uneven bars in 1952 and bronzes at the Soviet Championships in horse vault in 1952-54. After finishing her sporting career, Kalinchuk worked as a gymnastics coach in Moskva (Moscow).

name: Frank Høj Jensen
special_notes: Brother of Poul Richard Høj Jensen

name: Hans Petter Buraas
description: In his Olympic début and with flaming orange/red hair, Norway’s Hans Petter Buraas shocked the ski world and went on to win the slalom gold medal at Nagano in 1998, after rallying on his second run to win in a total time of 1:49.31. He had finished the first run trailing the reigning World Cup slalom champion, Austrian Thomas Sykora, by 22-hundredths of a second, but completed the second run almost 1.6 seconds faster than the Austrian. A snowboarding enthusiast, who has dyed his hair white, green, and then orange/red for the 1998 Olympic season, Buraas missed Salt Lake City 2002 due to injury, and was unable to duplicate his previous Olympic success in Turin 2006, where he did not finish the slalom. Buraas competed in slalom at four World Championships, finishing eighth in 2007 in Are, Sweden, and, in the three others, was disqualified (2003) or did not finish (1999, 2001). At the World Junior Championships, Buraas won the bronze medal in the giant slalom in 1994 at Lake Placid, USA (also 25th in super-g) and had two top-20 finishes in 1993 (17th in giant slalom, 19th in super-G). Buraas’ 10 seasons on the World Cup produced one podium victory (slalom) in 2000 at Sestriere, Italy, and nine more podium finishes (four seconds, five thirds). Buraas made his international début in a 1991 FIS slalom race in Norway. In 2001, Buraas had what first appeared to be a minor spill in training in Norway, but it turned into a career-threatening injury, requiring neck surgery for two disc dislocations. He attended Norwegian Toppidrettsgymnas in Baerum, and was introduced to the sport by his engineer father Bjorn, at the age of seven.
special_notes: Brother-in-law of Tiril Sjåstad Christiansen

name: Raúl Foullón
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–0–1 1974 Santo Domingo JUD bronze: lightweight -71 kg)

name: Misael Rodríguez
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 2015 Toronto BOX bronze: middleweight -75 kg) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–1–0 2014 Veracruz BOX silver: middleweight -75 kg)

name: William Randall
description: Bridgend’s William Randall went to the 1924 Paris Olympics full of optimism, having enjoyed a remarkable spell of success leading up to the Games. The only Welshman to compete in the weightlifting events in Paris, he was the reigning Welsh lightweight champion. Less than a month before setting sail for France, Randall broke three Welsh records in one day at Bridgend, which meant he simultaneously held eight Welsh records. That all counted for nothing at the Olympics, where he was outclassed and finished 20th out of 22.

name: Trygve Brudevold
description: Trygve Brudevold’s bobsledding career hit its peak during the 1950s, when he participated in three World Cups (1953-1955) and two editions of the Winter Olympics as a member of the Norwegian four-man crew. In 1952 he was 12th among 15 teams, with Arne Holst, James Hayden, and Kåre Christiansen, and in 1956, alongside Arne Røgden, Arnold Dyrdahl, and Odd Solli, he was 11th among 21 squads. He was athletically active in other pursuits as well, such as skiing, and ran marathons in his 60s and 70s. Brudevold is much better known in Norway, however, as the founder of what became known as the Brudevold Group, a house building and land development company. Trained in masonry, he began his own company in 1946 and finished his first major project in 1949. He then expanded his business across Norway, and eventually took the company international, all of which made him very wealthy.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Reached the Age of 100 ()

name: Mariya Bespalova

name: Maurice Taillandier
description: Maurice Taillandier was a career military officer who reached the rank of colonel. He competed at the 1924 and 1928 Olympics in team sabre. Taillander was French champion with sabre in 1925-27, under the direction of Master Barbasetti.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–1–0 1922 Oostende silver: sabre)

name: Takaya Kurokawa
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–1–0 2002 Busan FBL silver)

name: Fred Warngård
description: Personal Best: HT – 54.83 (1936).

name: Alla Grishchenkova
description: Alla Grishchenkova, the best Soviet female butterfly swimmer at the end of 1970s, competed at three major international tournaments during her career: the 1977 European Championships, the 1978 World Championships, and the 1980 Olympics. She medaled only at the 1980 Olympics, however, winning bronze in the medley relay. Her best individual result was also from the 1980 Olympics, when she was eighth in the 200 fly. Domestically, Grishchenkova won four Soviet titles, doubling in the 100/200 fly in 1978-79. She also won two silver medals at the Soviet championships, the 1977 100 fly and the 1978 4x100 free relay. Personal Best: 100 m butterfly – 1:03.49 (1979); 200 m butterfly – 2:15.70 (1980).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–1–1 1979 Ciudad de México SWI silver: 200 m butterfly, bronze: 100 m butterfly) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Aquatics Championships (0–0–1 1978 West Berlin SWI bronze: 4×100 m medley relay (swam in heats only))

name: Shuzo Kanda
description: Kanda Shūzō was a western style (yōga) painter from Hiroshima who studied under Nakamura Fusetsu and Ishii Hakutei. He was a member of the Ichisuikai art group. He was one of several winners of the prize at the first Nika Exhibition in 1914. He was also a member of the jury at the Hiroshima Inten Exhibition and portrayed American deaf-blind author Helen Keller. Kanda later made numerous trips abroad. In 1955, he began to draw the “atomic bomb ten installments” and was committed to the establishment of the Hiroshima Peace Art Exhibition. A major exhibition presented his work posthumously in 1978. Part of his painting Marathon from 1936 could be identified on a photo of the Japanese hall of the art exhibition in Berlin.

name: Lynn Colella
description: Lynn Colella started competitive swimming at the age of 10 and her first international success came in 1971 when she won two golds and a bronze at the Pan-American Games. After her silver medal at the Olympics she placed third in both the 200m breaststroke and 200m butterfly at the 1973 World Championships. Her younger brother, Rick Colella, won four Pan-American Games gold medals and joined his sister on the 1972 Olympic team. Aided by a scholarship from the Phillips Petroleum Co., Lynn earned a degree in electrical engineering from the University of Washington, where she later pursued postgraduate studies.
special_notes: Sister of Rick Colella Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (2–1–1 1971 Cali SWI gold: 200 m breaststroke and 200 m butterfly, silver: 4×100 m medley relay, bronze: 100 m breaststroke) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (3–0–0 1970 Torino SWI gold: 100 m butterfly, 200 m medley, and 4×100 m medley relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Aquatics Championships (0–0–2 1973 Belgrade SWI bronze: 200 m breaststroke and 200 m butterfly)

name: Téofilo Davis
description: Téofilo Davis finished fifth in the 1955 Pan American Games 110 metres hurdles and seventh in the high jump. Personal Bests: 110H – 14.6 (1951); HJ – 1.91 (1953).

name: Soha Abed Elaal
description: Soha Abed Elaal was active in archery during the 2000s, a decade during which she won several Egyptian national and African titles. She also set an Arab record in the 50 metres event during this time. She made her international début at the 2003 World Indoor Championships, but had her greatest successes in the second half of the decade. At the 2007 Pan Arab Games, she won the 50 metres competition and was runner-up in the 30 metres. She was then selected to represent Egypt at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, where she was 63rd in the women’s individual event. She also took part in the archery World Cup earlier in the year. Following her retirement from active competition, she worked as a coach.

name: Nikolaj Pešalov
description: Nikolai Peshalov had the following podium finishes at major championships: 2nd in the 1992 Olympics Featherweight class (305.0 kg); 3rd in the 1996 Olympics Bantamweight class (302.5 kg); 1st in the 2000 Olympics Featherweight class (325.0 kg); 3rd in the 2004 Olympics Lightweight class (337.5 kg); 2nd in the 1989 World Championships Featherweight class (307.5 kg); 1st in the 1990 World Championships Featherweight class (297.5 kg); 1st in the 1993 World Championships Bantamweight class (305.0 kg); 1st in the 1994 World Championships Bantamweight class (302.5 kg); 3rd in the 1995 World Championships Bantamweight class (295.0 kg); 2nd in the 1998 World Championships Featherweight class (317.5 kg); 2nd in the 1989 European Championships Featherweight class (307.5 kg); 2nd in the 1990 European Championships Featherweight class (287.5 kg); 1st in the 1991 European Championships Featherweight class (302.5 kg); 1st in the 1992 European Championships Featherweight class (312.5 kg); 1st in the 1993 European Championships Bantamweight class (295.0 kg); 1st in the 1994 European Championships Bantamweight class (297.5 kg); 1st in the 1995 European Championships Bantamweight class (305.0 kg); 1st in the 1997 European Championships Bantamweight class (290.0 kg); 3rd in the 1999 European Championships Featherweight class (312.5 kg); 1st in the 2000 European Championships Featherweight class (325.0 kg); 1st in the 2001 European Championships Featherweight class (300.0 kg); 3rd in the 2002 European Championships Middle-Heavyweight class (395.0 kg); 2nd in the 2004 European Championships Lightweight class (330.0 kg). He set five featherweight world records – three in the clean & jerk, and two in the total. Peshalov started his career lifting for Bulgaria, but later emigrated to Croatia and competed internationally for them from 1998.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Set a World Record in Weightlifting (bantamweight -59 kg (1993-1997) Clean & Jerk – 13 November 1993 - end: 167.5 kg (13 November 1993; Melbourne, Victoria, AUS) (competed as Nikolay Peshalov for Bulgaria), 168.0 kg (19 November 1994; İstanbul, TUR) (competed as Nikolay Peshalov for Bulgaria), 170.0 kg (3 May 1995; Warszawa, POL) (competed as Nikolay Peshalov for Bulgaria), bantamweight -59 kg (1993-1997) Total (biathlon) – 13 November 1993 - 22 July 1996: 305.0 kg (13 November 1993; Melbourne, Victoria, AUS) (competed as Nikolay Peshalov for Bulgaria))

name: Edwin Lins
description: Edwin Lins had the following finishes at major championships – 1987 World Championship: 90.0 kg. Freestyle (9th); 1988 European Championship: 90.0 kg. Freestyle (6th).

name: Anna Croci
description: Anna Croci had the following placements at major international championships - Dance: 1989 World Championships (15th); 1990 World Championships (14th); 1991 World Championships (15th); 1992 World Championships (13th); 1989 European Championships (13th); 1990 European Championships (8th); 1992 European Championships (11th) (with Luca Mantovani [ITA]).

name: John Peterson
description: John Peterson attended a small school, the University of Wisconsin at Stout, graduating in 1972. At the 1972 Olympics, he was defeated by the USSR’s Levan Tediashvili, who would later defeat his brother, Ben, at the 1976 Olympics. After college, John Peterson competed for Athletes-in-Action and had his best years in 1975 and 1976. He won the AAU Championship in both years was champion at the Midlands Tournament in 1975. In Montréal he defeated another Soviet, Viktor Novozhilov, to win the middleweight division. He later became a wrestling coach with Athletes-in-Action.
special_notes: Brother of Ben Peterson

name: Armin Garnreiter
description: West German archer Armin Garnreiter finished tenth at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics in the individual event. With the national recurve team, he won a silver medal at the 1979 World Championships. Garnreiter won 11 national titles between 1976-2009. In 2002, 2004, 2008 and 2017 he also won the team title.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Archery Championships (0–1–0 1979 Berlin silver: Recurve team)

name: Sarah Noriega
description: Sarah Noriega played volleyball for the United States at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. She played in college for Loyola Marymount University from 1994-97, leading them to three West Coast Conference titles, and being named the 1997 West Coast Conference Player of the Year. Noriega won a silver medal at the 2002 World Championships and a bronze medal at the 1999 Pan American Games. She was inducted into the Loyola Marymount Hall of Fame in 2009 and the Kansas Volleyball Association Hall of Fame in 2012.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1999 Winnipeg VOL bronze) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Volleyball Championships (0–1–0 2002 GER silver)

name: Henk van Heuckelum
description: Although he was a Dutch national in 1900, Henk van Heuckelum played for both Houdt Braef Stand from The Hague and the Léopold Club in Bruxelles in 1900 and 1901, eventually settling for Belgium. He was included in the Belgian selection from the University of Bruxelles that competed at the Paris Olympics, playing as a forward in their only match against a French team.

name: Gisela Sailer
description: At the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics West German sports shooter Gisela Sailer finished sixth in the air rifle event. With the air rifle team, she won the World Championships in 1983. She also won several national titles, all with the air rifle.

name: Sam Dickson
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (1–1–0 2014 Glasgow RGS silver; 2018 Gold Coast RGS gold)

name: Michael Seibert
description: Michael Seibert competed in ice dancing with Judy Blumberg and together they won the US title five years running, 1981-85. They also competed at the World Championships from 1980-85, winning bronze medals in 1983-85, placing fourth in 1981-82 and sixth in 1980. They then skated professionally, and won the World Cup Dance Championship in 1988 and 1989 and the World Professional Dance Championship in 1988. After their professional career, Seibert became a choreographer for figure skating and was the lead choreographer for Stars on Ice.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Figure Skating Championships (0–0–3 1983 Helsinki bronze: ice dancing; 1984 Ottawa bronze: ice dancing; 1985 Tokyo bronze: ice dancing)

name: Marcel Rohner
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Bob & Skeleton Championships (0–2–1 1996 St. Moritz bronze: Four-man; 1997 Königssee silver: Four-man; 1999 Winterberg silver: Four-man) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Bob & Skeleton Championships (FIBT/IBSF) (0–2–0 1996 Calgary silver: Four-man; 1999 Cortina d'Ampezzo silver: Four-man)

name: Charles Horter
description: Charles Horter graduated from Drexel University in 1970 and took up a career in real estate management. He was one of America’s most talented sailors in the Dragon class. Horter won the pre-Olympic regatta in Kiel in 1971 in addition to being the Atlantic Coast champion in 1970 and 1971, and the Pacific Coast champion in 1972.

name: Bertrand Hémonic
description: Bertrand Hemonic had the following podium finishes at the Flatwater World Championships: 3rd 2009 C1 4×200 m (with Mathieu Goubel, William Tchamba, and the non-Olympian Thomas Simart).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Marathon European Championships (0–1–0 2005 Týn nad Vltavou silver: Men's C1) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Marathon World Championship (1–0–1 2003 Valladolid gold: C1; 2006 Tremolat bronze: C1) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint World Championships (0–0–1 2009 Dartmouth bronze: C1 4×200 m)

name: Eirik Kvalfoss
description: Aged 19, Eirik Kvalfoss was fourth in the 10 km sprint at the 1979 World Junior Championships. Two years later he won his first World Cup victory in Anterselva, Italy. He was 1982 World Champion in the 10 km sprint in Minsk, where he placed second in the 20 km and won another silver medal in the relay. He defended his world sprint title at Anterselva in 1983. In the 1984 Sarajveo Olympics he again won the sprint, placing third at 20 km despite five penalty minutes, and he earned a silver in the relay. From 1982-91 Kvalfoss was world champion three times (his third gold came in the 1989 20 km) and had five silver medals and five bronze medals. In the Olympics however, although competing again in 1988 and 1992, he was not able to win more medals after his 1984 success. Kvalfoss used a couple of seasons to adapt to the skating technique introduced in 1985, and five of his 12 World Cup victories came in the period 1988-91 with the new technique. He won the World Cup in the 1989/90-season, and was known for his ability to give all he had at the final stage of a race. Kvalfoss was Norwegian champion nine times. He carried the Norwegian flag at the 1992 Opening Ceremony in Albertville, but failed to qualify for the 1994 Lillehammer Games and then ended his biathlon career. Kvalfoss married in 1994, settled in Oslo and has worked in the insurance business as a marketing manager.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Biathlon Championships (3–5–5 1982 Minsk gold: 10 km sprint, silver: 20 km and 4×7.5 km relay; 1983 Antholz gold: 10 km sprint, bronze: 4×7.5 km relay; 1985 Ruhpolding silver: 10 km sprint; 1989 Feistritz an der Drau gold: 20 km, silver: 10 km sprint, bronze: 4×7.5 km relay; 1990 Minsk/Oslo/Kontiolahti silver: 10 km sprint; 1991 Lahti bronze: 10 km sprint, 20 km, and 4×7.5 km relay)

name: Becky Turner
description: Becky Turner started out in artistic gymnastics for three years before switching to rhythmic. She was on the US national rhythmic gymnastics team from 1994-97, competed at the 1994 World Championship and the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, and won a silver medal in group at the 1995 Pan American Games. She also competed at the 1996 World Championships, and placed second in the group (hoops) at the 1995 Four Continents Championships. Turner attended Kennesaw State University in Georgia after the Olympics. She later taught and coached rhythmic gymnastics at Elite Rhythmic Gymnastics in Downers Grove, Illinois.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 1995 Mar del Plata RGY silver: group)

name: Egon Winter
description: Field hockey player Egon Winter was an Austrian team member at the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics. The team finished ninth and last in the tournament. They lost all matches in the preliminary round, scoring only one goal, against Denmark. Wildam also played ice hockey with Wiener (Vienna) AC in winter. As a Jew, Winter fled to Australia during World War II and settled in Sydney and took the name Egon “Frosty” Miller. In Australia he became a well-known ice hockey player and later coach of Melbourne Blackhawks IHC in the 1940s.

name: Ernst Knoll
description: Ernst Knoll wrestled in both freestyle and Greco-Roman style at the Olympic Games. At Mexico City in 1968, he was eliminated in both styles after the first rounds of the middleweight class. In 1972, at München, he competed only as a freestyler in the light-heavyweight division, but was again eliminated early. In 1967, Knoll had his best international finish when he was fourth at the European Championships. From 1964-72 he won nine West German national titles. Knoll came to West Germany as a young boy with his family, immediately after World War II, having been displaced from the Sudetenland. Until his early death at the age of 56, he owned a small metalworking company in his hometown Eppelheim.

name: Juan Maegli
special_notes: Father of Juan Ignacio Maegli Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (0–1–1 1993 Ponce SAI bronze: Hobie Cat; 2014 Veracruz SAI silver: J-24)

name: Tommaso Marconi
special_notes: Brother of Nicola Marconi Brother of Maria Marconi Cousin of Michele Benedetti Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Aquatics Championships (1–0–2 2002 Berlin DIV bronze: synchronized springboard; 2004 Madrid DIV gold: synchronized springboard; 2006 Budapest DIV bronze: synchronized springboard) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Diving Championships (0–0–1 2009 Torino bronze: synchronized springboard)

name: Ondřej Berndt
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Winter Universiade (0–0–1 2013 Trentino ALP bronze: combined)

name: Jason Parker
description: Jason Parker was a sport shooter who competed at four Olympic Games from 2000 to 2012. He initially focused on air rifle, competing at the Olympics in that event in 2000, 2004, and 2008, but later in his career had success in small-bore rifle and appeared in that event in at the 2008 and 2012 Olympics. Parker won five medals at the Pan American Games, with four golds in the 2003, 2007, and 2011 small-bore event, and a gold in air rifle in 2007. He won the 2002 World Championships in air rifle and has four bronze medals from the 2002 and 2006 Worlds. While shooting Parker was a member of the US Army Marksmanship Unit. He attended Xavier University, graduating in 1996 with seven All-American selections as a member of the Xavier rifle team. Parker helped the 1996 Xavier air rifle team win the NCAA title. In individual NCAA competition, Parker placed second at the NCAA in small-bore in 1993, while in air rifle he placed third in 1994, fourth in 1995, and fifth in 1996. Parker was inducted into the Xavier Athletic Hall of Fame in 2002.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (4–0–1 2003 Santo Domingo SHO gold: small-bore rifle 3 positions; 2007 Rio de Janeiro SHO gold: 10 m air rifle and small-bore rifle 3 positions; 2011 Guadalajara SHO gold: small-bore rifle 3 positions, bronze: small-bore rifle prone) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (1–0–4 2002 Lahti gold: 10 m air rifle, bronze: 300 m standard rifle 3 positions team and 10 m air rifle team; 2006 Zagreb bronze: 300 m standard rifle 3 positions team and 50 m small-bore rifle 3 positions team)

name: Dionisio Carreras
description: Dionisio Carreras Salvador, also known as El Campana, was a Spanish long-distance runner who enjoyed his best success during the 1920s. Carreras began running to cover the long distances from town to town in the Spanish countryside where the infrastructure lacked any form of public transport. The football team Zaragoza FC first took advantage of his local fame as a runner and employed him as their caretaker. In 1924 Carreras won the Media marathon, which was used to select athletes for the Paris Olympics. He ran in the marathon at the 1924 Paris Games where he finished in a very credible ninth place. He later admitted that he could have finished in a better position if he had not made a mistake in the final kilometres of the race. Over the next few years he won multiple long-distance races in Spain including becoming the Spanish marathon champion in 1928. Carreras was selected to run in the marathon at the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics but an illness prevented him from competing. Personal Best: Mar – unknown.

name: Aftantil Xanthopoulos
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (2–0–1 1997 Bari WRE gold: freestyle heavyweight -97 kg; 2001 Tunis WRE gold: freestyle heavyweight -97 kg; 2005 Almería WRE bronze: freestyle heavyweight -96 kg)

name: Tricia Stennes
description: Tricia Stennes was a short-track speed skater who competed in short-track demonstration events at the 1988 Calgary Winter Olympics. She was only in middle school when she made the 1988 US Olympic Team. She also skated long-track and also tried to make the 1988 Olympic Team in those events. Stennes was also on the 1992 US Winter Olympic team, marked for the relay, but she did not skate. She later became a team coach in 2010 for USA Speedskating at the Marquette (Michigan) Olympic Training Center.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Winter Universiade (0–0–1 1993 Zakopane STK bronze: 3000 m relay)

name: Yun Nam-Jin
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (2–0–0 1986 Seoul FEN gold: épée team; 1990 Beijing FEN gold: épée team)

name: Claude Dallaire
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–2 1983 Caracas WLT lightweight -67.5 kg bronze: snatch and total)

name: Kyle Salyards
description: Kyle Salyards was a breaststroker who swam the 200 breaststroke at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. He also won a gold medal in the event at the 2003 Pan American Games. Salyards swam at the University of Georgia, winning an NCAA title in 2004 and two Southeastern Conference titles. He continued to swim after the Olympics but retired after not making the 2004 Olympic team. Salyards was inducted into the Susquehanna Valley Chapter of the Pennsylvania Sports Hall of Fame in 2013.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 2003 Santo Domingo SWI gold: 200 m breaststroke)

name: Lothar Krieg
description: Lothar Krieg was a 400 metre runner who won a bronze medal with the 4x400 relay at the 1976 Montréal Olympics. He would also have been nominated for the 1980 Moskva Olympics but could not start due to the US-led boycott. He won titles in the 4x400 relay at the 1977 World Cup, and 1977 and 1979 European Cups. At the 1978 European Championships Krieg finished fourth in the 400. He was German Champion in the 400 in 1976. Krieg was educated as a sports teacher and coached sprinters with Eintracht Frankfurt. In 1987-88 he worked as the 400 national coach. He eventually became Director of Leisure and Fitness Sport for employees and trainees at the Frankfurt Airport AG (later Fraport AG). Personal Best: 400 – 45.64 (1976).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–0–1 1977 Sofia ATH bronze: 4×400 m relay)

name: Sachiko Yamazaki
special_notes: Mother of Kazuya Kaneda Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (3–0–1 1978 Bangkok SWM gold: 100 m freestyle, 4×100 m freestyle relay, and 4×100 m medley relay, bronze: 200 m freestyle)

name: Donald Bayley
description: Donald Bayley finished tenth in the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games lightweight class (685 pounds).

name: Arnd Neuhaus
description: Power forward Arnd Heuhaus was on the German basketball squad that finished seventh at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics after winning the classification match versus Puerto Rico, 96-86. In total, he earned 66 international caps On the club level, Neuhaus played with Duquesne University (USA, until 1989), TSV Bayer 04 Leverkusen (1989-91), Brandt Hagen (1991-99), and Schwelmer Baskets (1999-2002). He earned the German Cup in 1994. He later became a tax consultant and occasionally worked as a basketball coach.

name: Remigijus Lupeikis
description: Remigius Lupeikis competed for the Soviet Union prior to the break-up of that country and in 1986 won a gold medal in the team pursuit at the World Junior Championships. Later racing for Lithuania, he had a long career in the professional peloton, riding through 2002, including appearances at the 1996 and 2000 Olympics. As a professional he was never chosen to ride the Tour de France, but did race the Vuelta a España in 1992 and 1997, and the Giro d’Italia in 1992. His biggest professional victories came in winning the 1994 Tour of Berlin and the 2000 Tour of Egypt. He was also Lithuanian champion in the individual time trial in 2000 and in the road race in 2002, placing second in the Lithuanian Championship in the road race in 2000 and the time trial in 2002. On the track, Lupeikis won a silver medal at the 1995 World Championships in the point race.

name: Salvador Vergés
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (1–0–0 1979 Split ROW gold: eights)

name: Uwe Schmitt
description: Uwe Schmitt, a 400 hurdler, also ran the 4x400 relay at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games but was eliminated in the semi-finals of both the 4x400 and 400 hurdles. In 1987 he did not qualify for the second round of the 400 hurdles at the Worlds. Schmitt was overshadowed throughout his career by his teammate, Harald Schmid. In 1995, only 34-years-old, Uwe Schmitt committed suicide by taking poison. Personal Bests: 400 – 45.9 (1984); 400H – 49.39 (1985).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Committed Suicide (Committed suicide by taking poison.)

name: Rick Carey
description: Rick Carey was the greatest backstroke swimmer in the world in the early 1980s. At four consecutive major internationals – the 1982 World Championships, the 1983 Pan Americans, the 1984 Olympics, and the 1985 Pan Pacifics – Carey won the backstroke triple, winning gold in the 100 and 200 backstrokes, and the medley relay. In 1983 he was named Swimmer of the Year by Swimming World. At the 1984 Olympics, after winning the 200 backstroke, Carey was sullen in a televised interview because he had not broken the world record, was chastised in the press for his attitude, and then apologized to the American public in his next interview after winning the 100. During his career Carey set nine world records, including five individual world marks, three in the 100 in 1983, and two in the 200, his final world record coming at the 1984 US Olympic Trials. He also set 27 American records and won seven NCAA titles while swimming at the University of Texas. He was inducted into the International Swimming Hall of Fame in 1993. Carey stopped swimming competitively after the 1985 Pan Pacs and went back to school at Iona College, earning degrees in mathematics and computer science in 1987. He eventually entered the financial world, working with Merrill Lynch, UBS, and JP Morgan Chase in both New York and London.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (3–0–0 1983 Caracas SWI gold: 100 m backstroke, 200 m backstroke, and 4×100 m medley relay) Listed in Olympians Who Set a World Record in Long Course Swimming (100 m backstroke – 6 August 1983 - 15 March 1988: 55.44 (6 August 1983; Fresno, USA), 55.38 (6 August 1983; Fresno, USA), 55.19 (21 August 1983; Caracas, VEN); 200 m backstroke – 3 August 1983 - 21 August 1984: 1:58.93 (3 August 1983; Fresno, USA), 1:58.86 (27 June 1984; Indianapolis, USA); 4×100 m medley relay – 7 August 1982 - 25 September 1988: 3:40.84 (7 August 1982; Guayaquil, ECU), 3:40.42 (22 August 1983; Caracas, VEN), 3:39.30 (4 August 1984; Los Angeles, USA), 3:38.28 (18 August 1985; Tokyo, JPN)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Pan Pacific Swimming Championships (3–0–0 1985 Tokyo gold: 100 m backstroke, 200 m backstroke, and 4×100 m medley relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Aquatics Championships (2–1–0 1982 Guayaquil SWI gold: 200 m backstroke and 4×100 m medley relay, silver: 100 m backstroke) Listed in Olympic Swimmers - Doubles Champions, Same Year (1984 100/200 Backstroke Champion.)

name: Günther Heidemann
description: Welterweight boxer Günther Heidemann from Berlin won a bronze medal at the 1952 Helsinki Olympic Games, after losing his semi-final against Poland’s Zygmunt Chychła on a narrow 2-1 decision. Heidemann qualified for the Olympics by winning the German national team in Olympic year. He lost to Chychła again in the quarter-finals at the 1953 European Championships. He won his second national title in 1955 and at the Europeans that year lost his second round bout to the eventual champion Nicky Gargano from Great Britain. Heidemann, a trained bricklayer, later coached talented youths at his home club. The 1952 Olympic bronze medals were not awarded until 1971, when the Finnish Boxing Federation decided to hold the medal ceremonies for the 1952 boxing bronze medal winners. Initially the AIBA only wanted to award gold and silver medals. All 20 losing semi-finalists were invited to a ceremony in Helsinki but only six were able to appear, four of them were the losing Finnish semi-finalists, along with Heidemann and Boris Nikolov of Bulgaria.

name: Katherine Plouffe
special_notes: Twin sister of Michelle Plouffe Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 2015 Toronto BAS gold)

name: Yarianna Martínez
description: Personal Best: TJ – 14.42 (2011).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–0–1 2007 Bangkok ATH bronze: triple jump, 2009 Beograd ATH gold: triple jump)

name: Alla Butova
description: Alla Butova took up speed skating in 1963 and was on the Soviet national team from 1968-73. Mainly a sprinter, Butova competed at the 1972 Olympics, finishing 8th in 500 m and at the 1972 and 1973 World Sprint Championships, finishing 15th and 21st, respectively. Domestically Butova never won a Soviet title, winning the 500 m distance silver in 1969 and sprint all-around silver in 1972 at the Soviet championships. After finishing her sport career, Butova worked as a teacher-coach at a local sports school in Ivanovo, where she was also deputy director of teaching and educational work for nearly 30 years. Personal Bests: 500 – 43.7 (1973); 1000 – 1:32.3 (1970); 1500 – 2:23.6 (1970); 3000 – 5:06.4 (1970).

name: Lee McNeill
description: A sprinter out of East Carolina University, Lee McNeill ran the 4x100 relay at the 1988 Seoul Olympics. He twice won international gold medals in the relay, at the 1987 Pan American Games and the 1987 World Championships. At the 1985 World University Games, McNeill was third in both the 100 metres and with the 4x100 relay. In the 100 metres McNeill was runner-up at the TAC Meet in 1985 and third in 1988, famously outrunning Carl Lewis in the semi-finals in 1985. That summer he won the 100 at the US Olympic Festival. At the NCAAs, he was fourth in 1985 and third in 1986 in the 100. In 2010, McNeill was inducted into the Robeson County Sports Hall of Fame in Pembroke, North Carolina. Personal Best: 100 – 10.99 (1988).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1987 Indianapolis ATH gold: 4×100 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–0–2 1985 Kobe ATH bronze: 100 m and 4×100 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (1–0–0 1987 Rome gold: 4×100 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Died After Contracting the Coronavirus (COVID-19) ()

name: Tsugio Hasegawa
description: Tsugio Hasegawa, a student from Keio University, never won a title at national championships in figure skating. He started with a fourth place in 1932 and finished in the top three at four tournaments (1933-35, 1937). A second place in 1935 earned him a place on the team for the 1936 Winter Olympics in Garmisch-Partenkirchen. On the expedition to Europe, Hasegawa entered the European Figure Skating Championships in Berlin, but did not start. After the Olympics he was ranked 17th at the World Championships in Paris. At home, Hasegawa took the title at the student championships twice, in 1935 and 1939.

name: Ernest Townsend
description: Brit Ernest Townsend studied at the Derby College of Art, Heatherleys in Chelsea and the Royal Academy of London, and lived in Derby for most of his life. As a professional artist, he painted portraits of many local and national politicians, industrialists, and professional notables. One of Townsend’s best known works was the creation of a design for the roofs of the Rolls-Royce aircraft engine factories in Derby so that they would appear to German bombers to resemble a village. One of his best known portraits was Winston Churchill from 1915, which was not presented to the public until 1944.

name: Giovanni Casale
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–1–0 2005 Almería JUD silver: half-lightweight -66 kg)

special_notes: Wife of Hironao Meguro Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Winter Games (0–1–0 2003 Aomori BIA silver: 4×6 km relay (competed as Kanae Suzuki))

name: Josef Prokeš
description: Josef Prokeš was a Czechoslovakian cross-country skier who competed at the 1956 Cortina Winter Olympics. He also appeared at two World Championships in the 1950s. After ending his competitive career Prokeš worked at Charles University in Praha, but later became a ski coach. He emigrated to Austria where he established a Nordic training centre in Stams, Tyrol. Prokeš is considered the founder of the cross-country ski movement in Austria.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Winter Universiade (0–1–0 1960 Chamonix CCS silver: 4×8 km relay)

name: Deng Shudi
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (2–0–0 2018 Jakarta/Palembang GAR gold: rings and team)

name: John Mayasich
description: John Mayasich is one of the greatest hockey players to ever play for the Minnesota Gophers. He played from 1952 through 1955 and made All-America for three straight years, capturing the Western Collegiate Hockey Association scoring title in both of his last two years. In addition, he still holds the NCAA tournament record for the most points scored in one game – seven against Boston College in 1954. His career after leaving college was also distinguished. He declined several professional offers to continue playing amateur hockey, mainly with the Green Bay Bobcats. He played internationally for the United States more than any other man – playing on the 1956 and 1960 Olympic teams, and on the World Championship teams of 1957, 1958, 1961, 1962, 1966, and 1969. John Mayasich is remembered at his college by the annual presentation of the Mayasich Award, given to the best student-athlete on the hockey team. He went to forge a career in the radio and television industry and served a twelve year term as president of the Hubbard Broadcasting Corporation.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (1–1–1 1956 Cortina d’Ampezzo (Olympics) silver; 1960 Squaw Valley (Olympics) gold; 1962 Colorado Springs and Denver bronze)

name: Sancho
description: Sancho, who was Catalan, was born in the province of Castellón, but raised in Sants, a Barcelona neighborhood. He started his career with CE Sans in 1915, but moved to FC Barcelona after only one season. He played midfield, and as there was no professional football at that time in Spain, worked as a bricklayer, and won two Copa del Rey (Spanish Cup) titles and four Campeonato de Cataluña titles, but after some criticism, especially about his weight, he joined the nascent UE Sants in 1922, only to move back to FC Barcelona after one season when he was convinced to return. During his second time with that team he again won two Copa del Rey titles and three Campeonato de Cataluña titles. During the 1920 Olympics, where the Spanish national team played their first-ever match, he played in two of the five matches. Additionally he earned one more cap in 1923 against Portugal, bringing him a total number of three caps without scoring. After his active career he had some short stints as coach. Sancho died in the morning of the 25 August 1960 after stomach problems.

name: Marc Agosta
description: Personal Best: Mar – 2-17:35 (1985).

description: Men: 1997 World Championships (FNR); 1998 World Championships (FNR); 1999 World Championships (17); 2000 World Championships (FNR); 2001 World Championships (FNR); 2002 World Championships (20); 2003 World Championships (21); 2004 World Championships (28); 2005 World Championships (25); 1996 European Championships (FNR); 1997 European Championships (20); 1998 European Championships (FNR); 1999 European Championships (21); 2000 European Championships (16); 2001 European Championships (11); 2002 European Championships (16); 2003 European Championships (7); 2004 European Championships (17); 2005 European Championships (15).

name: Yelena Dementyeva
special_notes: Wife of Maksim Afinogenov Listed in Olympic Champions Who Have Played in a Fed Cup Final Winning Team (Olympic Gold - 2008; Fed Cup - 2005)

name: Nevio De Zordo
description: Nevio De Zordo comes from a family of “gelatieri” (ice cream makers). In 1959 they moved to Cologne, Germany, and the family managed an ice cream parlor in Cologne-Sülz for 40 years. The winter spent the family at their native Italian home in the Dolomites, so that De Zordo could train on the bob track in Cortina d’Ampezzo. In 1969 he became World Champion in the two-man and in 1970 in the four-man bobsled. In addition, he was twice silver medalist at World Championships, in 1967 in the two-man and in 1965 in the four-man bob. De Zordo also was 1964 European Champion in the two-man bobsled. After he missed the 1968 Winter Olympics due to an injury, his only Olympic medal came at the 1972 Winter Olympics in Sapporo in the four-man bob. He was a pilot in all his international appearances, ending his active career after a disappointing performance at the 1976 Winter Olympics. At home he never won an Italian title, but between 1963 and 1970 placed second six times (three each in the two-man and four man-bob) and third twice, both times in the four-man bob. He later ran a cafe on the premises of Cologne University.

name: Jean Racle
description: Jean Racle had the following placements at major international championships - Pairs: 1968 European Championships (18th) (with Fabienne Etlensperger (a non-Olympian) [FRA]). 1971 World Championships (14th); 1973 World Championships (14th); 1974 World Championships (13th); 1971 European Championships (10th); 1972 European Championships (11th); 1973 European Championships (8th); 1974 European Championships (12th) (with Florence Cahn [FRA]).

name: Éric Koloko
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (2–1–0 1975 Al-Jaza'ir GYM gold: horse vault and team, silver: parallel bars)

name: Juan Ríos
description: Juan Ríos was a Puerto Rican tennis player who achieved a career-best singles ranking of #261 in the world in October 1991, and a doubles ranking of #277 in the world in November 1987. Ríos played on Puerto Rico’s Davis Cup team in 1992 and 2004. Ríos had his best success at the Central American and Caribbean Games where he won gold in the doubles and bronze in the team event in 1986, and won a silver medal in the doubles in 1990. He competed in the singles and doubles at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics but did not advance past the first round in either event.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (1–1–1 1986 Santiago de los Caballeros TEN gold: doubles, bronze: team; 1990 Ciudad de México TEN silver: doubles)

name: Santiago de la Parte
description: Personal Best: Mar – 2-11:10 (1984).

name: Mark Moore
description: Mark Moore attended the US Naval Academy at Annapolis, graduating in 1960. In 1960 the Naval Academy eight won the title at the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen (NAAO) meet, which doubled as the Olympic Trials. The Midshipmen eight placed fifth at the 1960 Olympics, breaking the US streak of winning the rowing eights, which extended from 1920-56.

name: Daniela Brendel
description: German breaststroke swimmer Daniela Brendel won the silver medal with the 4x100 IM relay team at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics, although she only swam in the heats. She also started in the 100 metres and the 200 metres individual events where she finished eighth and tenth respectively. In 1990, she was the last national champion in the former GDR in both events. In 1992, she won the 200 metres title in re-unified Germany.

name: Kurt Ettinger
description: Fencer Kurt Ettinger was Austrian champion in foil (1923, 1929, and 1931) and sabre (1928 and 1931). He was a team member of the Austrian Olympic foil teams at the 1924 Paris and the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics, reaching the second round on both occasions. Individually, he was eliminated in the foil in the semi-finals at both Games. Ettinger won foil a team silver medal at the 1933 World Championships, and bronze in 1931 and 1937. Ettinger was an Austrian Jew who left Austria for Paris at the time of the German “Anschluss”. In May 1941 he went to the USA and became a US citizen, changing his first two names from “Kurt Erich” to “Curtis Thomas”. He served in the US Army during World War II from December 1942 to July 1943, and later died while on a family vacation at Innsbruck, Austria.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–1–2 1931 Wien bronze: foil team; 1933 Budapest silver: foil team; 1937 Paris bronze: foil team)

name: Fumiyuki Beppu
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–1–1 2018 Jakarta/Palembang CRD silver: road race, bronze: individual road time trial)

name: Clive Wright
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1987 Indianapolis ATH bronze: 4×100 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (0–0–1 1987 Rome bronze: 4×100 m relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–2 1990 Auckland ATH bronze: 4×100 m relay and 4×400 m relay)

name: Björn Siegemund
description: Björn Siegemund was a German badminton player who was eliminated in the first round at the 2000 Sydney Olympics in both the men’s doubles, partnering Michael Helber, and mixed doubles partnering Karin Stechmann. In 2004 at Athens he partnered Nicol Pitro and reached the second round in the mixed doubles. Siegemund won ten German national titles. He later married Danish badminton player Rikke Olsen and became brother-in-law of her sister Lotte. He later turned to coaching and coached the Brokers Tigers in the Barfoot & Thompson New Zealand Badminton League.
special_notes: Husband of Rikke Olsen Brother-in-law of Lotte Olsen

name: Nathan Katz
special_notes: Brother of Josh Katz Son of Kerrye Katz

name: Veronika Bauer
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Freestyle Ski Championships (1–1–0 2001 Whistler-Blackcomb gold: aerials; 2003 Deer Valley silver: aerials)

name: Ryszard Zub
description: Ryszard Zub took up fencing in 1949 and was on the Polish national team from 1955-64. A sabre fencer, Zub won all his international honors in the team event. He won team silvers at the 1956 and 1960 Olympics and a team bronze at the 1964 Olympics. He was also team world champion in 1959 and 1961-1963, while taking a team bronze at the 1957 World Championships. Domestically Zub won individual sabre silver at the 1959 Polish Championships and was on the Polish team champions from 1962-1966. After finishing his sporting career, Zub worked as a fencing coach at first in Poland and in 1970 moved to Padua, Italy. His most famous pupils were Olympic team sabre champions Michele Maffei, Mario Aldo Montano, Marco Marin and Gianfranco Dalla Barba.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (3–0–0 1959 Budapest gold: sabre team; 1961 Torino gold: sabre team; 1963 Gdańsk gold: sabre team)

name: Cornelius Righter
description: Swede Righter was a football and basketball star at Stanford and also played on the rugby team in 1917. Football was undoubtedly his major sport and he received honorable mention in the 1920 All-America selections. After graduating in 1921 he became football, basketball, and track coach at the College of the Pacific for 12 years. He later served as a coach at several small Northern California colleges and high schools until his retirement in 1962.

name: Horst Meyer
description: Rower Horst Meyer was a member of the eights at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics that won the silver medal. The boat from Ratzeburger RC was the so-called Deutschland-Achter (Germany Eight), which won the 1962 World Championships and the 1963-65 European Championships. Meyer also won West German Championships in the eights from 1962-68. In 1964, Meyer was awarded the Silver Bay Leaf, the highest sports award in West Germany. Meyer stayed in the new eights crew after 1965 and won a gold medal at the 1968 Mexico City Olympic Games. This crew then carried the Olympic flag into the stadium at the 1972 München Olympics. He also won golds at the 1966 Worlds and the 1965 and 1967 Europeans. He was also on the boat at the 1965 Henley regatta when it defeated the United States. Meyer later studied business economics and headed a consulting company. He was also on the board of the Deutsche Sporthilfe (German Sports Aid), and was elected to the National Olympic Committee several times. He also became involved in the peace movement, which led to the founding of the “Athletes for Peace against Nuclear Warriors” initiative. After German reunification, this movement had less influence and essentially disbanded.
special_notes: Bearer of the Olympic Flag at the opening ceremony of the 1972 Summer Olympics

name: János Steinmetz

name: Hugo Budinger
description: Like no other, Hugo Budinger, played a role in post-war West German field hockey as a player, coach, and official. With the West German team, the 58 times capped international from Rot-Weiss Köln (1951-61) was captain of the team that won the surprise bronze medal at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. He was also on the team at the 1952 Helsinki Games when Germany were beaten 1-0 by Netherlands in the quarter-final. He competed in his third Olympics in Rome in 1960, when the team finished seventh. Budinger was a member of the West German team that won the unofficial European Championship in 1954. Previously, “Mister Hockey” had revolutionized European field hockey with ideas following a trip to Pakistan, including the introduction of the so-called twist grip. Budinger at that time worked as a lecturer at the German Sports College in Cologne. After his playing career he was the sporting director of the West German Hockey Federation (DHB) from 1961-1969 and also served as the national head coach. In 1968, the national team under his leadership finished in fourth in the Mexico City Olympics and won a World Cup bronze medal in 1973. In all, Budinger served his sport for 26 years ranging from a player to DHB Vice President. In 1974 he co-founded and was head of the Trainer Academy of the German Sports Federation in Cologne up to 1993. In 1979, at the age of 52, he promoted sports science and, in 1990, he was appointed honorary professor on the grounds for his work in the field of movement and training. Budinger was a member of the West German National Olympic Committee, and from 1993 was a member of the Council of Elders. In the 1990s he also committed himself to the German Golf Federation, and in 2011 he was inducted into the German Sports Hall of Fame.

name: Rudi Schumann
description: Rudi Schumann finished an unfortunate fourth with the East German volleyball team at the 1968 Mexico-City Olympics. The Soviet bus was stuck in traffic prior to their match against the GDR and they were 90 minutes late for the match. The East Germans could have taken a forfeit, but elected not to, and the USSR won the match in five sets. Had the USSR defaulted, Czechoslovakia would have won the gold medal, and East Germany would likely have won a medal. After returning home, the supposedly amateur East German players received the same rewards from the government usually accorded to silver medalists. In 1972 he won a silver medal, the GDR team losing the final against Japan 3-1. Schumann played on the winning East German team at the 1969 Volleyball World Cup and the 1970 World Championships at Bulgaria, which is still the greatest title in German volleyball history. The team won the deciding game against Bulgaria 3-2 in a dramatic fifth set. The team was 8 points behind (5-13), but came back to win sensationally, 15-13. Nationally Schumann played with SC Leipzig, winning 13 national titles from 1963-65, and from 1967-76, and in 1964 the European Cup of Champions. In total, he earned 204 caps. He later became a sports teacher and volleyball coach at DHfK Leipzig and the University of Leipzig. Schumann also worked for the International Volleyball Association.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Volleyball Championships (1–0–0 1970 BUL gold)

name: Heinrich Wallner
description: Heinrich Wallner was an Austrian three-time Olympic Nordic skier from 1968 at Grenoble to 1976 at Innsbruck. He did not achieve a higher place than 38th over 15 km at Sapporo in 1972. In 1970 he won his only individual Austrian national title, also over 15 km. He added seven consecutive relay titles with Tyrol from 1964-70.

name: Robert Diggelmann
description: Robert Diggelmann wrestled for Switzerland at the 1948 London Olympics. Diggelmann became known in Switzerland for his lifelong dedication to fitness, practicing yoga and lifting weights into his 90s, and eating a mostly plant-based diet. In 2003 he appeared on a Lucerne television show and demonstrated his fitness, at age 79, by doing 96 squats with a 50-kilogram dumbbell on his shoulder. Diggelmann worked as a stonemason.

name: Robert Schneider
description: Robert Schneider raced the road race at the 1972 Olympics, but did not finish. He is far better known for his career in economics. Schneider graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1968 and later earned a PhD in economics from Wisconsin in 1977. He then served for three years in the Peace Corps in Niger. Schneider initially taught environmental and agricultural economics at Williams College until 1981. He then worked as an economist for the International Monetary Fund from 1981-88. In 1988 Schneider moved to The World Bank, where he worked as an economist for almost 20 years, serving as a member of the World Development Report Team in 2003. While at The World Bank, he was lead sustainable development economist for Latin American, and a sector leader for agricultural and the environment for Brazil.

name: Karel Saitl
description: Karel Saitl took up weightlifting during World War II, but did not reach his peak in the sport until the 1950s. He won the Czechoslovakian national championship in the bantamweight division in 1951, 1952, and 1953 and attended the 1952 Helsinki Olympics, where he placed tenth. He had more success at the European Championships, where he took silver in 1953 and bronze in 1956, and the World Championships, where he won bronze in 1952 and 1953. He also trained for the 1948 London Olympics, but was ultimately unable to attend. In his later years, he competed internationally in masters’-level tournaments and continued to do so into his 80s.

name: Rainer Podlesch
description: In 1968, cyclist Rainer Podlesch was a member of the West German pursuit team, but was injured after the quarter-final and replaced by Jürgen Kissner. The team then reached the pursuit final against Denmark. The Germans always led and the race looked over when, after 9 of 12 laps, a Danish rider went off the back. However, they re-grouped but still trailed at the bell. The German team then began to split, with Jürgen Kissner dropping off the pace. As his teammate Karl Heinz Henrichs passed him, Kissner’s hand appeared to touch him, possibly giving him a slight push. Germany held on to win by 3½ seconds, but Kissner was an East German defector and East Germany immediately protested that the touch had been an illegal shove. After a 15-minute conference among the judges, West Germany was disqualified, and Italy and the Soviet Union were announced as the silver and bronze medal winners. FRG officials then protested, stating that Italy and the Soviets should not be placed ahead of their riders. Another long conference ensued, and the result was announced as Denmark first and Italy third. No silver medal placement was given until a meeting of the Fédération Internationale Amateur de Cyclisme (FIAC, later the UCI) in November, when West Germany was awarded second place and their silver medals. Rainer competed again at München four years later as a member of the West German 100 km time trial team, finishing 20th. In 1978 and 1983 he won the Motor-paced World Championships and also won three silver and three bronze medals. Until his retirement in 2013 he was the motor-pacing representative for the West German Cycling Association. Podlesch’s brother Karsten was also a cyclist and Rainer’s son Carsten became the last UCI World Motor-paced champion as an amateur in 1992, and was also the very last professional champion two years later.

name: Hartmut Schelter
description: Sprinter Hartmut Schelter finished fifth with the 4x100 relay at the 1968 Mexico City Olympics, where he also reached the semi-finals of the 100. The same year Schelter won East German titles in the 100, 200, and with the 4x100 relay. He was trained as a skilled textile worker. Personal Best: 100 – 10.1 (1968).

name: Jorge Giannini
description: Jorge Giannini was a member of the gold medal winning team at the 1971 Pan American Games.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1971 Cali HOK gold)

name: Jörg Schmidt
description: East German flatwater canoeist Jörg Schmidt won the gold medal at the 1982 ICF Flatwater Canoe World Championships in the C-1 1,000 event. In 1988, at the Seoul Olympics he collected a silver medal. Due to the Soviet-led boycott of the 1984 Los Angeles Games, he could not participate. Domestically, Schmidt won five East German national titles. He was married to Birgit Fischer-Schmidt from 1984 until 1993 when they divorced. Schmidt was a trained electrician employed by the Nationale Volksarmee (National People’s Army).
special_notes: Husband (divorced) of Birgit Fischer-Schmidt Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint World Championships (1–0–0 1982 Beograd gold: C1 1000 m)

name: Ove Aunli
description: Ove Aunli qualified for the Norwegian World Championship team at Lahti in 1978, and won a bronze medal as a member of the Norwegian relay team. Two years later he placed third in the 15 km event at the Lake Placid Olympics, and added a silver medal in the relay. At Oslo in 1982 Aunli finally won a World Championship gold medal in the relay, and two years later in Seefeld anchored the Norwegian team to victory in a close battle with Italy’s Giuseppe Ploner. Aunli struggled at the Sarajevo Olympics in 1984, when, after recording the fifth best time in the 15 km event, he was disqualified for using the skating technique during the last 200 m, and in the 50 km he failed to finish. In the relay the Norwegian team was outside the medals for the first time in 20 years, placing a disappointing fourth. Aunli’s last international medal came in the relay at the 1987 World Championships, when the Norwegian team finished third. His only national championship title came in 1985 when he won the 30 km. He was third in the overall World Cup both in 1981 and 1985, and ended his international career after the 1987 season. Ove Aunli married future World and Olympic Champion Berit Kvello in 1979. They later ran a sport shop together in Ove’s birthplace Kyrksæterøra.
special_notes: Husband of Berit Kvello-Aunli Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Nordic Ski Championships (2–2–4 1978 Lahti CCS bronze: 4×10 km relay; 1980 Lake Placid (Olympics) CCS silver: 4×10 km relay, bronze: 15 km; 1982 Oslo CCS gold: 4×10 km relay; 1985 Seefeld CCS gold: 4×10 km relay, silver: 30 km, bronze: 50 km; 1987 Oberstdorf CCS bronze: 4×10 km relay)

name: Oliver Grüner
description: West German rower Oliver Grüner was a member of the quadruple sculls at the 1988 Seoul Olympics that finished sixth in the final. In 1988 and 1990 he won the German quadruple sculls national title and, in 1989 and 1991, also won the double sculls national titles. Together with André Steiner he won the double sculls bronze medal at the 1991 World Championships.

name: Per Røntved
description: Denmark’s Per Røntved was one of the best football defenders of his era. Røntved made his senior début when he was 18 for Brønshøj BK in 1967. Initially playing as a midfielder, he moved back to a defender, making 116 appearances for the club where he scored 48 goals. In 1972 Røntved moved to West Germany to play for Werder Bremen in the Bundesliga where he made almost 200 appearances for the team. In 1979 he moved back to Denmark to play more than 100 matches with Randers Freja before making his final club appearances with Hvidovre IF in 1983. Røntved played his first match for the Danish national team in 1970. Two years later he captained the team at the 1972 München Olympics where he played in six matches and scored a goal against Brazil. In August 1981 Røntved became the most capped player for Denmark when he played in his 63rd match. Just over a year later he earned his 75th and final international cap, a national record that lasted until 1985. During his international career Røntved captained the Danish team in 38 matches. Røntved was named the Danish Football Player of the Year in 1972 and was inducted into the Danish Football Hall of Fame in 2011.

name: Donald Knight
description: Donald Knight had the following placements at major international championships - Men: 1963 World Championships (8th); 1964 World Championships (9th); 1965 World Championships (3rd); 1966 World Championships (7th); 1967 World Championships (4th).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Figure Skating Championships (0–0–1 1965 Colorado Springs bronze: singles)

name: Håkan Spik
description: Personal Best: Mar – 2-13:57 (1980).

name: Ernst Jirgal
description: Ernst Jirgal studied the German language and literature and then worked as a teacher at the Federal Educational Institution in Wiener Neustadt. He later taught at secondary schools in Wien, Linz, and Baden. After the Anschluss of Austria he went into internal emigration. As director of the Tivoli Day Care Center from 1947, he was able to implement his pedagogical principles. Beginning in 1954 until his untimely death he taught at secondary schools. As a writer, Jirgal published volumes of poetry, stories, essays, and dramas, but he was best known for his poetry. He was also editor of the literary magazine Plan from 1945-47 and received the Austrian State Prize for Poetry in 1950. His text Sports Cantata was written in 1952 and there is an audio recording read by Jirgal himself. In the same year the poem was set to music by Austrian composer Gerhard Wimberger (1923–2016). In 1954, this _Sports Cantata _ for tenor, baritone, choir, and chamber orchestra was performed by the Vienna Symphony Orchestra in the Vienna Concert Hall in a program together with the Olympic Hymn by Spiros Samaras.

name: Stubby Kruger
description: Harold “Stubby” Kruger was a Hawaiian native who swam for the Healani Club. He swam the 100 backstroke at the 1920 Antwerpen Olympics, placing fifth. Kruger was third in the event at the 1920 US Olympic Trials. Kruger later became an actor and stuntman, often filling in for Douglas Fairbanks or Spencer Tracy. He died in Los Angeles but was buried in Honolulu.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Acted in Movies (Mutiny on The Bounty, Spartacus)

name: Julien Bogaert
description: Julien Bogaert started canoeing in 1940, after the German occupation of Belgium. He raced with KKYKC from Kortrijk, which at the time was the strongest canoeing club of Belgium. He competed in the kayak singles in London 1948, where he was eliminated in the heats. Bogaert retired from the sport in 1952, to focus on his business in saws.

name: Ray Hicks
description: Three weeks after his 17th birthday in 1934, Ray Hicks showed his potential as a serious cyclist when he won a 1-mile handicap race at Chichester, Sussex. Before the year was out, he had emulated that performance with victories in both 1- and half-mile events. The following year, Hicks won both the NCU London Centre and Southern Counties 1,000-metre sprint titles. In 1936, he was beaten in the final of the NCU One Mile Grass Track Championship by the crack rider Dennis Horn but won the Polytechnic Club’s 1,000-metre time trial and was second, with Bob Meller, in the NCU National Tandem Championship at Herne Hill. After winning the Olympic sprint trial, Hicks was selected for the sprint and time trial at the Berlin Olympics. The following year he competed in the sprint at the World Championships in København, but chances of a medal were ruled out when he was involved in a training accident the day before the start of the sprint. He still bravely competed, having lost three nails off his heavily bandaged right hand, a lot of skin from one of his thighs, and suffered ankle injuries. In 1938 Hicks took part in the British Empire Games at Sydney, and on this occasion, won a silver medal behind fellow Englishman William Maxfield in the 10-mile track scratch event. He also took part in the sprint and track time trial.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 1938 Sydney CYC silver: 10 miles scratch (competed for England))

name: Fritz Steuri
description: Fritz Steuri was a Swiss skier, ski jumper and mountain guide. Steuri’s father, also named Fritz Steuri, was a renowned mountain climber and Nordic and Alpine skier. In the winter of 1931/32 Steuri worked as a ski instructor in the United States. Early in 1932, Steuri competed in two events at the 1932 Lake Placid Olympics. Steuri finished in 18th place in the ski jump and in 26th place in the Nordic combined. After the Olympics, Steuri spent six months on an expedition of the west coast of Greenland. Steuri also continued to ski competitively, winning the 1935 Swiss Ski Championship, which consisted of four disciplines (cross-county, ski jump, downhill, and slalom). In 1939, Steuri was part of another expedition, this time of the Himalayas with the Swiss Foundation for Alpine Research. While climbing the Chaukhamba mountain in the Garhwal region, the group was hit by an avalanche, which resulted in the deaths of two of the team, although Steuri survived. The expedition was called off once the group found out about the outbreak of World War II.

name: Hans Möhr
description: Hans Möhr was born in Maienfeld, a small town near the Swiss border with Austria and Liechtenstein. Initially he worked as a farmer, but later he trained young military horses for the Swiss Army, as until 1972 Switzerland was the last country in Europe with a cavalry. In 1960 and 1964 Möhr participated in the Olympics as an individual rider, and in 1964 he also started in the team event. His biggest success, besides his Olympic participations, was winning the 1964 Grand Prix of Switzerland at the CSIO in Lucerne together with his 1964 Olympic horse Troll . He and Troll also won the Lonsdale Trophy in puissance (a variant of high jumping) at the 1963 Royal International Horse Show at White City, London.

name: Dirk Knappheide
description: Modern pentathlete Dirk Knappheide was on the West German Olympic team at the 1988 Seoul Olympics and finished 15th with the team and 60th individually. Four years later at Barcelona he represented re-unified Germany and finished 11th with the team and 15th individually. In 1993, he won his only German national title. Knappheide later turned to triathlon and won several competitions in senior classes. He also founded a fitness and physiotherapist center in his hometown of Warendorf.

name: Åke Andersson
description: Playing ice hockey, football and bandy, Åke Andersson played his entire career from 1932-57 with Hammarby IF. His best accomplishments came in ice hockey, when he won six Swedish titles (1936, 1937, 1942, 1943, 1945, 1951) and was capped 134 times with the Swedish national ice hockey team between 1937-54. Starting as a forward (he was a leading goal scorer at the 1936 Swedish Championships), Andersson switched to defense in the mid-40s and after World War II was captain of the Swedish national team until his retirement from international hockey in 1954. Andersson won an Olympic bronze in 1952 and was World Champion in 1953, while taking silvers at the 1947 and 1951 World Championships and bronze at the 1954 World Championships. He was a European Champion in 1951-53, while taking silver in 1947 and 1954 and bronzes in 1948-50. He also won silver at the 1941 Unofficial European Championships. Andersson was capped six times with the Swedish national bandy team between 1937 and 1951. He was awarded the Stora Grabbars Märke (Big Boys’ Badge) #24 in ice hockey and Stora Grabbars Märke #51 in bandy, a Swedish sports honorary award created in 1928 by Bo Ekelund. After finishing his sporting career, Andersson worked as a coach with Hammarby IF.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Ice Hockey Championships (3–3–2 1947 Praha silver; 1948 St. Moritz (Olympics) bronze; 1949 Stockholm silver; 1950 London bronze; 1951 Paris gold; 1952 Oslo (Olympics) gold; 1953 Zürich and Basel gold; 1954 Stockholm silver) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (1–2–2 1947 Praha silver; 1951 Paris silver; 1952 Oslo (Olympics) bronze; 1953 Zürich and Basel gold; 1954 Stockholm bronze)

name: Hermann auf der Heide
description: The German field hockey team won the silver medal at the 1936 Berlin Olympics after losing 8-1 to India in the final. Defender Hermann auf der Heide played in the 6-0 win over Denmark in the group stage. He won five international caps between 1936-42. At the club level he played for Turnverein Sachsenhausen 1857 and won the German Championship in 1939 and 1943. His brother Eberhard was also a field hockey player.

name: Cathy Lee Irwin
description: Cathy Lee Irwin had the following placements at major international championships - Women: 1970 World Championships (10th); 1972 World Championships (9th); 1973 World Championships (12th).

name: Alfonso Pérez
description: Alfonso Pérez had the following podium finishes at major championships: 2nd in the 1971 Pan American Games Lightweight class.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 1971 Cali BOX silver: lightweight -60 kg)

name: Gabriele D'Annunzio
description: Gabriele D’Annunzio was an Italian poet, journalist, novelist and dramatist belonging to the late-romantic representatives of Fin de Siècle symbolism. At the height of his success, D’Annunzio was celebrated for the originality, power and decadence of his writing. His role in politics is controversial due to his influence on the Italian Fascists movement and his status as the alleged forerunner of dictator Benito Mussolini. He is often seen as a precursor of the ideals and techniques of Italian fascism. In 1922, shortly before the march on Rome, he was pushed out of a window by an unknown assailant, surviving although he was severely injured and did not completely recover before Mussolini had been appointed Prime Minister and hailed by the fascists as duce del fascismo. In 1924 D’Annunzio was ennobled by King Victor Emmanuel III and given the hereditary title of Principe di Montenevoso. In 1938 he died of a stroke. He was given a state funeral by Mussolini and was interred in a magnificent tomb constructed of white marble. It is unknown which of his works was submitted in 1912. In 1910, however, his novel Forse che sì, forse che no (Maybe - maybe not) about the infancy of aviation appeared. D’Annunzio lived in Paris from 1910-15 and could have been personally approached by Pierre de Coubertin, urging him to participate. In 1924 D’Annunzio was also a jury member of the art competitions.
special_notes: Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Principe (Prince) di Montenevoso) Listed in Olympians of Royal Blood (Principe di Montenevoso)

name: Sandra Paintin
special_notes: Wife of Andrew Paul

name: Daniel Herberg
description: German curler Daniel Herberg finished sixth at both the 2002 Salt Lake City and the 2010 Vancouver Winter Olympics. In 2004, he won the silver medal at the World Championships and, in 2002 and 2004, gold medals at the Europeans. In total, he participated in eight World Championships. Domestically, Herberg played with EC Oberstdorf. By profession, he became a project developer.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Curling Championships (2–0–0 2002 Grindelwald gold: team; 2004 Sofia gold: team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Curling Championships (0–1–0 2004 Gävle silver: team)

name: Jenő Ébert
description: Jenő Ébert had the following placements at major international championships - Men: 1963 World Championships (14th); 1965 World Championships (19th); 1966 World Championships (15th); 1968 World Championships (19th); 1963 European Championships (8th); 1964 European Championships (12th); 1965 European Championships (14th); 1966 European Championships (13th); 1967 European Championships (12th).

name: Raúl Chapado
description: Personal Best: TJ – 16.87i (1998).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–0–1 2001 Tunis ATH bronze: triple jump)

name: Hermann Smiel
description: Hermann Smiel, the first Olympian from Cottbus, finished 76th in the 315 km individual road race at the 1912 Stockholm Olympics, which was held as an individual time trial. This helped Germany finish sixth in the team road race, although he was not among the top four German finishers. Germany was the only 11 man-team to have all squad members finish the race. In 1912 Smiel was fourth in the Berlin-Wien (Vienna) race over 550 km. In 1923 he was one of the founders of the future classic cycling race, Cottbus-Görlitz-Cottbus. Until his death, Smiel contributed to cycling in Lausitz, and was a founding member of his home club RK Endspurt Cottbus 09. In 1950 Smiel started the cycling section at Progress Cottbus and took care of youth cyclists. In 1952, 40 years after his start at the Olympics, Smiel did a lap of honour on the Stockholm course. His two sons also became track sprinters and road cyclists.

name: Willi Montag
description: West German rower Willi Montag Fitze was a member of the coxless fours at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. The boat was eliminated in the repêchage semi-finals, after finishing third behind second-placed qualifier Italy by over nine seconds. Montag rowed in the coxless fours for ETUF Essen, was runner-up at the West German Championships in 1955, and won the title in 1956. In 1956 the boat also won the bronze medal at the European Championships and the following year he won the gold medal. Therefore the members were awarded the Silver Bay Leaf, the highest sport award that the German Government awards to sportsmen.

name: Martina Accola
description: A slalom specialist, Switzerland’s Marina Accola made her Olympic Winter Games début at Lillehammer in 1994, where she finished 17th. At the 1998 Nagano Olympics, she had a slalom finish of seventh. Accola had three slalom podium finishes in the 1997 European Cup, two World Cup podiums (second in 1995, third in 1997), and three-times she was a silver medalist at the National Championships (1996-98). Her first international competition was the 1992 World Cup in Schruns, Austria, where she finished 21st in the slalom. Accola’s parents Paul (a farmer) and Anna lived next to a ski hill, and Martina started skiing at the age of eight. She had three brothers, two older ones, Andreas and Paul, and one younger one, Thomas. Paul was a five-time Olympian in alpine skiing, winning a bronze medal in the combined event at the 1988 Winter Games in Calgary. He was the 1992 World Cup overall champion and a three-time World Championships medalist (one silver, two bronze). While skiing, Martina Accola worked as a business clerk. Her hobbies included badminton, tennis, cooking and reading, and she had pet chickens.
special_notes: Sister of Paul Accola Cousin of Beni Hofer

name: Patrice Lhôtellier
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (2–2–2 1987 Lausanne silver: foil team; 1989 Denver bronze: foil team; 1991 Budapest bronze: foil team; 1997 Cape Town gold: foil team; 1998 La Chaux-de-Fonds silver: foil team; 1999 Seoul gold: foil team)

name: Jim Curran
description: Jim Curran skied briefly for the US Ski team, competing at the 1992 Winter Olympics in the 50K, finishing 56th. In the early 1980s, Curran was the Nordic Director at the Prospect Mountain Ski Center in Woodford, Vermont. He started out as a downhill skier but switched to cross-country while at the University of Vermont. Curran later became a building contractor and painter in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, but as of 2009 still competes in cross-country skiing at the local level.

name: Richard Stithem
description: Richard Stithem graduated from Steamboat Springs High School in Colorado in 1971, and then attended Northeastern Junior College in Colorado. He started sliding in 1977, but did not compete at his first national championship until 1980. Stithem made the Olympic team in his first attempt at national competition.

name: Filiberto Mercado
description: Filiberto Mercado had the following podium finishes at major championships: 2nd in the 1959 Pan American Games road race team (with Francisco Lozano and Jacinto Brito).
